titleStmt.title: The true copy of a Welch sermon preached before Prince aurice in Wales upon his departure thence by Shon up Owen, Priest. VVherein is desired that Prince Maurice would not plunder her townes and villages, for they were all poore men and not able to buy her a new cushion to make her preach on. For which sermon Iohn up Owen was committed to prison, put by her benefice, and exiled the country: whereunto is added John up Owens complaint for her sad losse.

titleStmt.title: The true copy of a Welch sermon preached before Prince aurice in Wales upon his departure thence by Shon up Owen, Priest. VVherein is desired that Prince Maurice would not plunder her townes and villages, for they were all poore men and not able to buy her a new cushion to make her preach on. For which sermon Iohn up Owen was committed to prison, put by her benefice, and exiled the country: whereunto is added John up Owens complaint for her sad losse.

notesStmt.note: Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

div.p: The true Copy of a Welch SERMON Preached Before Prince MAVRICE in Wales upon his departure thence, by Shon up Owen, Priest.
Wherein is desired that Prince Maurice would not plunder her Townes and Villages, for they were all poore men and not able to buy her a new Cushion to make her Preach on.
For which Sermon Iohn up Owen was committed to prison ‚Ä¢ ut by her Benefice, and exiled the Country. Whereunto is added Iohn up Owens complaint for her sad losse.

q.p: Now ther ‚Ä¢ fore, why disquietest thou thy selfe, (Prince Maurice,) seeing th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ art but a corruptable man? and why art thou moved (to come into these parts) whereas thou art but mortall?

p.hi: And why h ‚Ä¢ st thou not considered in thy mind this thing that is come, rath ‚Ä¢ r then that which is present?

div.p:
HEr Text divides it selfe, or rather falls into three peices of her owne accord; in which urds her shall find three generall parts: her first part is the Terminus ad quo; her second, Terminus ad quem; her third and last part is, Terminus ad quod. The Terminus ad quo is meant you (Prince Maurice) in these ourds: Now therefore, why disquietest thou thy selfe: that is, why commest thou into these her territories to disquiet us? Then the next or second part is, the Terminus ad quem; that is, to ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ know who sent for her hit ‚Ä¢ er; that is the qu ‚Ä¢ re: Then followes the third and last part, the Terminus ad quod, wherefore and for what her is co ‚Ä¢ e for; now Prince Maurice, or cousen Prince Maurice, which title her loves best, that her desires her to accept of: And now her having formerly brushed her owne Country-m ‚Ä¢ ns and omens coats and freeze j ‚Ä¢ tkins, and told um of her faults soundly, for her will have her caknow that her Countries podies are not troubled with many gownes, her will with her leave, and her owne priviledge being a Preacher, rub and brush her coats also Prince Maurice; and first her will begin with her habit, and tell her of her owne faults and imperfections in her garments, or ar ‚Ä¢ ayment; her cannot call her coate her‚ñ™ weares now, nor give it no better a terme then even a smocke of Roome,
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ iding coate, a C ‚Ä¢ valiarisme, or Antiprotestatisme coate, full of Idolatrous Romanisticall buttons‚ñ™ so thicke set in a popish ceremonious way, th ‚Ä¢ t even it is abhomination to her sigh ‚Ä¢ ; nor is this all her must tell her good Prince Maurice, for her will be bold to informe
her urship, that first the name of Maurice came out of this true‚ñ™ ancient, honourable Principallity of Wales, and it tooke her first originall from Morice-dancers, or one that did rise and caper oftner then her fellowes, and so called M ‚Ä¢ ri ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , or Maurice; be God, her country her can tell, never proved false, but were honest true Trojans, faithfull to her Kings and Queenes, and all her Princes; that is a credit for her owne Country, for her doth remember when her was but a Batchelour of Art, there was a true proverbe went up and downe her Country that is this: Three Welch-men, two souldiers, three English-men, two theeves; three French-men, two Traytors; three Spaniards, two whore-masters; three Italians, two Inglers; three Dutch-men, two Drunkards: which plainely shewes that you being a Dutch-man is most subject to bee intoxicated, ergo, overcome, or subject to her passions and her humours; for let her but aske her one question, nay, now her is in her Pulpit, her is in a place of Sanctuary, and may boldly talke her pleasure; what a Tivell made her to come into the Welch Alpes with her Troopers, and her D ‚Ä¢ agoneers, and her Pioneers, and her Ingineers? what, doe her thinke to undermine her Mountaines, & throw downe her huge pig hils, and lay them levill like her Lowcountries; no her warrant her; so much shall serve for her Introduction to the Text, to her cousen Prince Maurice; now suffer her to tell her a word of reproofe, which is this; Terminus ad quem, and l ‚Ä¢ st of all a word or two of admonition or advice, and then her will have done: As her said before, what a Tivell made her come, first come into England, secondly into her‚ñ™ Kingdom of Wales: could her not be content to stay at home in her owne Country, at the University of Leyden, a place her have heard of, but indeed-law her was never there; Leyden should be a place of dulnesse, or heavinesse, like Lead, which word Leyden is taken from Lead, for lead is the first silable to Leyden, that is, one that is heavy heeled, or hath lead in her shooes; I say, why did nother stay there, who sent for her hither? her saies againe and again, who sent for her hither? will her not answer? then her will declare, that it was malice, and envy; two of the eldest sons of the great Tivell; againe‚ñ™ what moved her to come in this warlike manners; has her any cause? was her not well used at Layden, had her not good Apparells, had her not good victuals, had her not good Hodg-podge mine-hoire there? had her not good educations and instructions in all the lib ‚Ä¢ rall Sciences; had her not there a schoole of war to exercise
her valours in, but her must come into England, and there spoile and plunder, burne and def ‚Ä¢ ce whole Townes and Villages; and bring her brave Country of England, the very fine Country of England to destruction, and to want Bread corne, and Barley-corne; Sirrah, sirrah her have heard that most of her victuals, as Beere, Corne, Mutton‚ñ™ Veale, nay even her apparrels that her have form ‚Ä¢ rly worne‚ñ™ hath bin sent her out of England to relieve her and the rest of her brethren when her was not able to helpe her selfe, but must have lived meanely, and gone with many a hungry belly to bed, and rose againe with as good an appetite as when her laid her downe and sl ‚Ä¢ pt upon it: And her doe thus ungratefully require poore England, to kill her men and omens, her fathers and her mothers, which often contributed out of her yearly meanes to help her, when her was as low as the bowle that runs in the Bowling-alley, who meets with many rubs by way; I say poore England, did help to succour her, when her was not able to helpe her selfe, no not wipe her arse; her might h ‚Ä¢ ve kept her as her have said at Leyden in Dutch-land, and have made her self a Captaine, and gone against Iack‚ñ™ Spaniard; there her should have found good causes and considerations for taking up of her arms, and for killing of men, there her s ‚Ä¢ yes, her should have been honoured of all the English Nation who had heard of her valours and her courages; or her should have gone with her sword into Ireland, and with her dexterious hand and inchanted body, have endeavoured to quell and refrigerate the hot Irish Rebells, whose c ‚Ä¢ uelty and inhumanity no Brittish Chronicle her can find in her country, nor in her own library, can parallell: There her must confesse her had gone and steered a right and a good course, even by the compasse of Christianity: but this course that her now takes is Diabolicall and S ‚Ä¢ tanicall, and prophane; nay her w ‚Ä¢ ll tell her her owne; and tell Belzephon which is the third Tivell in hell, her faults if her meet her in her way, and say her lyes in her tee ‚Ä¢ h if it be a lye; So may her tell her Maurice, that her is in a malignant and capitall fault, in such a grosse and barbarous manner exercised, that if her had one of her chiefe Shudges here, her would apprehend h ‚Ä¢ r, and bring a bill of Scandala Magnatum against her, and issue out a Fi ‚Ä¢ ry Facias against her; and by that means forfeit all her goods and lands by a premunire: So much shall serve for my first reproofe for England, sweet England, honey England, which is „Äà‚óä„Äâ
Terminus ad quem; now suff ‚Ä¢ r another word of the reproofe for
her comming in Wales, in this her posture and warlike manner, wch is her Terminus ad quem. And first, what did her meane to come into her borders, to spoile her brave orchards and gardens, her Cider and her Perry trees, what did her mean to do, to mar and change all her very good pippins and pom ‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢ ers into c ‚Ä¢ abs, and all her excellent Har ‚Ä¢ ichoak ‚Ä¢ s into thistl ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , and all her leeks and onions into brambles and thorns‚ñ™ and make it as barren as the place from whence her come; do her mean by‚ñ™ her guns and her cruelties to destroy all her cattells and her welch ven ‚Ä¢ sons, and fine plack Cowes‚ñ™ that her should have no butter nor toasted shee ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , or Cows-bobby: her do think that her do mean to make all things so dear in her Kingdom of Wales, as it is amongst your Butter boxes; as to make her pay double or taxcise for all her eates or drinks or wears, and that her sha ‚Ä¢ l in Wale ‚Ä¢ feed as her did in Holland upon rootes, and car ‚Ä¢ e ‚Ä¢ s, and onions, and hodg podg, that is, all sorts of hearbs sod together, which fils the Dutchmans hungry belly very well, as a little wh ‚Ä¢ y doth our hogs belli ‚Ä¢ s in our barns or stables; a turd is as good and farre wholsomer for a Sow then a P ‚Ä¢ n-pudding, No good Prince Maurice‚ñ™ her shall no ‚Ä¢
„Äà‚óä„Äâ suffered, her shall shew her no such Hocus Pocu ‚Ä¢
tricks; to do such ungodly deeds, and be suff ‚Ä¢ red to run on in h ‚Ä¢ r wilfulnesse; her has brave spirits in Wales left yet, though her lost many brave souldiers at Kenton battels, and her have long poles with pi ‚Ä¢ es or welch hooks at the end, such as can pul‚ñ™ her to her, or put her from her‚ñ™ for her will tell her Prince Maurice, if her do not go hence speedily, her souldiers wil be beaten to pieces, and her s ‚Ä¢ lfe hugged worse then the chiefest Tivell Belzebub did hug the witch, which will make her colour the long s ‚Ä¢ ams of her h ‚Ä¢ se, worse then new three penny ale doth, or a purge of
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ x vomic a given in a potion: her tell her, her has valiant men ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
Wales such as shall sirk her Toby for her, and tickle her galligascoin ‚Ä¢ , marke her that now, her will warrant her shall make all her ords good: therfore her say be gone, be gone her say young man; for her do hold her but a monster, because her teech is l ‚Ä¢ nger then her beard, be gone her advises her with her pag and paggage, and the rest of her lumb ‚Ä¢ rs; her cannot endure these farting guns, nor these fisling pistols, nor this stinking powder which shoot‚ñ™ nothing but pulle ‚Ä¢ s, and kill her C ‚Ä¢ untreym ‚Ä¢ n three or foure furlong ‚Ä¢ off; an ‚Ä¢ then her is dead before her knows who hurt her, or c ‚Ä¢ n‚ñ™ say her prayers or make her wills: therefore her gives her f ‚Ä¢ ire warnings, Prince Maurice, to be forthwith gone out of her Territories, and trudg home, and keep her good Queen her
mother company, as her elder brother the Paulsgrave doth, so her then may become an honest man, and it may be a good bowler. Her Countrey-men cannot endure to bee plundered and robbed of her
‚Ä¢ oods and parrels, nor of her cattels and venisons; her beleeves her would kisse where her sate a Sunday, if her had such fat goodly cattells as her has in Wales, in your Dutch-land Country: but her hop ‚Ä¢ s her cattells have more wit then to range out of their Countrey or from their Masters house, then to be enticed over sea with her when her goes; God send her good shipping; her cattell will her hope have more wit, and find lead in her feet, rather then go ‚Ä¢ o Leyden, if such a motion were made, or such a patent granted to any projector: so her should have done Prince Maurice, if he had had any wit or money: But her shalbe cozened as her Grandam dog was: her will tell her plainly her has no mony nor plate in Wales, and her parish is very poor, that her lives in, and her is the Parson of it; for her cannot put up at the quarters end not above ten groats at the most‚ñ™

Do ‚Ä¢ her but looke here, her Parishoners are not able to buy or al
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ her a new Cushion for her Pulpit, see how many holes and rents are in her Cushion; see how her feathers fly about, and how the Cony wool f ‚Ä¢ yes about her ‚Ä¢ ares, her is not able to afford her a new coat but once in two or three yeares: what did her meane to come hither? by God, her whole Cou ‚Ä¢ try is very poore; and her should be in a very pad condition if her had not good store of tyth Piggs, Hens, Capons, Eggs, and such like, her should not know how to subsist with her wives and children; so much shall be enough which her hath spoken for the Text, which is the Terminus ad quod; that is, wherefore, and for what her is come for into Wales, which her has told her sufficiently off‚ñ™ and her hopes will take notice and amend.

Now a word of Admonition, and so her will conclude, and that is this; her doe wish her Prince Maurice to goe her waies home quietly into her owne Country, goe her sayes young Prince Maurice home to her good Lady and Mother, as her have said before, for every honest man will doe as her is bidden, as her elder brother Prince Charles doth, and comfort her, who is very sorry to her knowledge, to hear ‚Ä¢ how her doth abuse her selfe and her Country of England; her good Lady and Mother is very heartily sorry for her rashnesse, goe home young Prince Maurice‚ñ™ and be obedient to her deare Mother; her hath sent for her two times already, and if her do ‚Ä¢ not goe before the third
time of sending, her will tell her plainely, that Prince Maurice is a Canary-bird, and her will send two Tivels and bid her take him Tivels take him; and if her Tivels has taken her they will so torment her podies, that her would have wished her had never come into England nor Wa ‚Ä¢ es, to fire, plunder, and rob all her meetes; and so her leaves her to her owne considerations and consciences, to apply all these sayings to her selfe: and her commits her prince M ‚Ä¢ urice to Dinner, because her smells the Roast meat and pyes piping hot, which stai ‚Ä¢ s for her upon the Table: and so her will end as her at first begun, that is with her Text; Now therefore, why disquietest thou thy selfe, (Prince Maurice) seeing thou art but a corruptable man? and why art thou moved (to come into these parts) whereas thou art but mortall: And why hast thou not considered in thy mind this thing that is come rather then that which is present Esdras 7. Verse 15, 16. Prince Maurice was very angry at this Welch-mans Sermon, and the Doctrines he made of it; commanded the Priest to bee committed to close prison, and that there should be another Parson chose in Iohn up Owens place; and withall commanded that the said Priest should bee banishe ‚Ä¢ the Country, and never to preach more in Welch; whereupon Iohn up Owen hearing of this sentence tooke it very patiently, and intends to come up to London and complaine to the House about‚ñ™ this his cruell sentence; and in the interi ‚Ä¢ falling into a merry Poeticall vain ‚Ä¢ writ these few lines, lamenting his hard fortune; called, Alas poore Welch Priest whither wilt thou goe.

div.opener: To the tune of alasse poore Scholler.

lg.l: Her parish so unkind is grown
Will leave her in the lu ‚Ä¢ ch.
Yet it is known that Sir Owen
Fire boyld their B ‚Ä¢ efe and Bacon.
But now like to her Pulpit
they say they made of wood were,
Her hath made to them of late
her gown from her and bang her,
poor Owen and halfe hang her
her w ‚Ä¢ ll never dam her,
To be one of th ‚Ä¢ se Wise-acres.
Yet now her think ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t better‚ñ™
That do know never a letter
Do get both wives ‚Ä¢ nd riches‚ñ™
no cloake nor yet no bree ‚Ä¢ hes.
By women her is wo ‚Ä¢ d
So, so so‚ñ™ her hath tricks now,
Owen will by her wits now
Alas poor welch priest it must needes be so.
